text: 750ml bottle pours a golden color with a bit of head. Peach skins, slight sourness, and tons of Brett lingers at the end.

My Bottom Line:
Juicy peaches momentarily turn to jam and candy before being awash in citrusy tartness and comfortable, natural bubbles.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A slice of foam covers the misty peach blond.
-Mouthfeel is lush and conducive to high drinkability.
-Peach flavors are nicely expressive while not wanting to dominate everything.
-Some sips feel like this is a more delicate Cantillon FouFoune.

Bottle.
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer. Wyśmienite piwo z cudownie bogatym brettowym charakterem i piękną owocowością.

sample from bottle, poured a cloudy dark golden orange colour with a light white head. nose of grains, cellar notes, funk, yeast, juicy fresh peach notes, light lactic notes, oak, barnyard funk, peach pits, and big stone fruits. taste is jammy peach flesh, oak, grains, and tart funk. to bad that there is a light notice of the high abv.
Bottle. Much of hay and barnyard. Some taste of dried apricots and hints of fresh peaches.
Bottle hazy light beige musty funky aromas lots of dry peach notes. Greg pale peach flavors and mild brettiness. Terrifically subtle.

Bottle shared at port Street courtesy of Nate Mcfeters, cheers! end of Bottle pours hazy amber with sizable pillowy white head. Earthy sharp pissy with peach undertones. Low carbonation, full bodied, boozy, earthy, minerally, Brett, almond, peach stones, some sweet fruit, just a hint of acetic acid, sharp lactic overtones, musty, dry, tart finish, pretty complex but perhaps still a little young bbe 2020 but plenty of aging time available

Bottle. Hazy orange liquid with medium white head. Aroma of peaches, funk, mineral, light vinegar, light wood and light lemon. Taste is dry and light to medium sour with notes of lemon, apple skin, funk, peaches and mineral. Medium bodied with medium to high carbonation. Nice, drinkable!

Bue en bouteille de 75cl. Biere excellente. Un coté sour très agréable, acide mais pas trop (à mon gout quoi). Des fruits bien présents, pêches douces et rondes. Une belle corpulence avec lalcool. Le tout très bien équilibré et long en bouche. Nickel !

Bue en bouteille de 75cl à la brasserie,
Couleur ambrée (pêche), belle mousse grosse effervescence
Nez sur le brett et la pêche
Attaque en bouche assez acide, acide lactique, yaourt à la pêche, brett, équilibre sur le malt et le bois.

Ojejujeju. W aromacie przepiękna brzoskwinia, morela, słodycz, szlachetność, bretty, lambici... Genialne. W smaku oszołomienie podtrzymane, wytrawna brzoskwinia wokół brettów, kwaśność stonowana, pijalne jak diabli, gładkie, dostojne. Piwo roku dla mnie.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2017 Aroma: barnyard, peach, pineapple
Taste: light sour, barnyard, pineapple, tart, peach

Bottle from Vinmonopolet in Valkendorfsgate, Bergen. Pours a hazy golden body with a large creamy white head of considerable longevity. Aroma is peaches, pale malts, citrus, smoke, brett-like funky farmhouse/saison yeast notes and hints of red fruits, wine gum, straw and pears. Taste is citrus, smoke, pale malts, peaches, straw and hints of mineral salts, apple peel and bretty funk notes. Medium body, high carbonation, smooth mouthfeel. The combination of smokey phenols from the brett and a great citric sour touch makes for a great drinking experience. Lovely complex and yet highly refreshing American farmhouse ale from Logsdon, the best Ive had from them so far.

Bottle, enjoyed four years before bbd. Pours hazy dark yellow, with a big creamy head. Aroma is peaches, musty fruit peel, barnyard and fruity brett, as well as wooden barrels. Medium to full body, with soft carbonation. Flavour is tart, with musty fruits and peaches, light farmhouse with perfumey bretty notes and wood, as well as light malts with cereals.

75cl bottle from Mother Kellys bottle shop. It pours a cloudy apricot color with a large off white head. Aroma is lightly tart and funky with a medium lingering sweetness and bold peaches and apricots notes, barnyard, light lemon, ripe melon, light wine esters. Taste is also medium sweet and tangy with notes of ripe mango, apricots and peaches, more barnyard funk and light citrus peel. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, excellent

Pours clear orange with a large frothy white head. Aromas of peach, bretta, apricot, funk, fruit jam. Taste is very fruity with almond notes and honey and tropical fruit jam with some funkiness. Mouthfeel is medium bodied and silky smooth yet restrained with moderate carbonation.

Pours clear light amber with low white head 
Aromas tart of peach juice , bretta, honey , 
Taste has tart notes of peach, honey , citrusy fruits, honey

Pours clear amber with a finger of white head. Aroma of peach, apricot, light elderflower, bretta, grass. Taste is mild tart with a lingering mildly funky sweet finish. Light and crisp body with average carbonation.

Bottle shared by mariuspoenari at Klooster Delft. Hazy golden poor with white head. Peachy smell, grapes, strawberry lemonade surup and peach up front, some interesting funk. Sweet malts, fruity peach and yeastiness. Medium sweet, light sour. Over medium body, soft carbonation. Soft chalky, minerallike feel. Fruity and sweet chalky finish.
Bottle shared at Klooster. Hazy orange with a thin white head. Notes of peaches, wood, light funk, mineral. Mediym body and carbonation and a mellow funky finish.

Bottle shared thanks to MariusPoenari. Murky orange golden with lasting white head. Peach, funk, lots of chalk and mineral, dank cellar, strong dusty, lots of bitter herbs and grass. Light sweet and sour with medium bitter finish. Over medium bodied with soft fizzy carbonation. I dont really get the high ratings, its very chalky and alcoholic.

From bottle, thanks to Klimaet. Aroma of peach, some oak and brett. Hazy golden with white head, lasting. Taste is light sweet, light sour and light bitter - more peach. Medium body, dry feel, peach brett finish.
Bottle in Seattle at Brouwers. Nice peach sour though not as explosively juicy as Id been lead to believe. Its still a must-try.

18.08.2016, 0,75l bottle sampled @ Café Sara:
Nice creamy mediumlasting head, slightly hazy. Aroma is slightly fresh fruity, peach, fruit stones, minerals, grass, hay, weeds, yeast, bark. Taste is slightly sour-ish dry fruity, sorrel, unripe peach, minerals, yeast, bark, grass, fruit stones, hay, soda powder. Medium bitterness, slightly sour-ish harsh mouthfeel. Nice enough.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2016 From bottle, shared with Jens and Thilde. Pours hazy golden amber with a small white head. Aroma of peaches (duh!), funk, lots of lemon peel, sweet candy, light yoghurt, light honey. Taste is light honey, lots of peaches, light yoghurt, lots of funk and barnyard, alcohol is no where to be found. Full mouthfeel, quite high carbonation. Intense fruit, borderline synthetic, but this is really good!!! Well worth the wait.

Pours a hazy orange from the bomber thin white head. Aroma is huge Brett funk with slight stone fruit. Taste is more toward the fruit with a hint of earth and lots of barnyard. Mild acidity, fruity, nice.

From notes. Enjoyed at Dougs house for the Epic Peach and Apricot debacle of a tasting that happened on July 9. 750 mL bottle. I am stoked to try this one! The pour is a golden amber color with a little haziness and a small off white head that falls down pretty quickly. The aroma is interesting. There is a funky peach juice all over it at the start, and then it moves through ha tart skin, light dustiness and into a spicy saison grain type of finish. Its pretty complex, and I wasnt expecting it. The flavor is a little more strange. There is a funky peach juice going on, but it tastes almost a little syrupy. The sourness doesnt hardly pop at all. There is a tart skin on the finish. The mouth feel is a little thicker and carries a softer carbonation. The after is almost a lightly sweet tart juice and a lingeringly funky dustiness. Its really interesting. Not sure how I feel about it entirely.

Yields a clouded amber-yellow color with a decent sized head. 

Lots of ripe, almost overripe peaches on the nose with an earthy quality and ice-tea sweet malts. A faint, funky, dusty sourness cuts through the prominent fruitiness, which reveals a luscious sweetness, reminding me of a peach jogurt.

Has a medium carbonation among a fuller body with a late dryness, coating up the sourness. 

Drinks with a heavy, fermented fruitiness from the very beginning, complimented by sweet, cakey malts and a creamy softness. Has a jogurty sourness, which gets accompanied by a perfumy peach fruitiness throughout. Finish with more acidic jogurt, still soft on the tongue with even more perfumy peach.

Seems a bit unbalanced to me due to the overly artificial, perfume dominance, which is pretty intense on both aromas and flavors. Got a nice, well fitting tartness, which adds to the richness of the peaches. Unfortunately its pushing too far, adding a distractive artifical flavor to the taste.

75cl bottle @ Finissons ces pétroles tasting, merci Kevin.
BB 01/2019; bottle # 5925.
Couleur orange, col blanc.
Bouquet est fort plaisant relevé par unf ruité de pêche assez développé. Retro-nasal de brett restant plus en retrait.
Palais brett perce sur un profil restant réchauffant des 10%, le profil de la pêche ajoute une certaine douceur., malté plaisant Assurant un fini caramel. Boisé ajoute une fine note épicée qui tranche bien avec le brett.

Tap at Ale Arsenal. This is an amazing palate cleanser. So light and refreshing, with the peaches really jumping out of the glass to create a clear aromatic and flavor profile. A little mellowing from the oak balanced well. I did not get a lot of Brett, but did not care!

Yowza. At the epic peach/apricot sour tasting. Aroma is peach funk juice, sweet, slight tart, wow. Appearance is amber golden, off white head, slight haze. Taste is peaches, funky as fuck, skins, barnyard, very saisonish, great. Mouthfeel is light body, light crisp carbonation, peach funk aftertaste. Overall, solidly good.

Style et résumé:  Coup de coeur. 
Comment: Merci Patrick. Bouteille #20101 best by 10/2020.
Portrait: Une robe jaune avec une mousse blanche. Un nez de pêche et de bonbon aux pêches comme ceux de Maynard. Une bouche intense, sèche avec des pêches qui ne veulent pas sen aller. Facile mais oh combien facile à boire. Avec ses 10 dégrées cest dangereux. Cette bière a peu de défaut. Les pêches sont là. Difficile de faire mieux.
Note:  9/10

Bottle best before 10/2020, from joenugs, shared with Nelson on 6/25/16.Massive amounts of head/carbonation as usual from Logsdon. Light yellow tint to its otherwise snow white color and a bright, clear, copper-canteloupe-golden body.Big peachy nose is almost all skin, lending leathery, spicy and even earthy notes to the otherwise well-malted (cookies and cream, dry caramel, vanilla) and moderately "bretted" nose. Some definite booze to it, though its not intense, with heavy lime and hickory nut skin on the finish mixing with the peach to add a unique complexity.Strong peach skin/pit in the flavor with white grape and heavily attenuated peach juice. Tons of acidity resulting with moderate brett tartness but also a bit of inelegant bread and heavy floral character from the brett. Lip smacking juiciness and a richly malted but fairly well attenuated texture with all of the full, fairly tight carbonation that comes with their beers. Maybe a bit too much carbonation and body, in the end with some booziness to boot. But the peaches are done better here, and uniquely so, than any other peach beer I can recall. So much leather, white grape, tart juice and wonderfully integrated with the malt.

750ml bottle. Shiny pale orange colour. Nice medium white head. Peach, hints of barnyard, pear, juiciness in the aroma. Peach, leathery and earthy notes at first. Hints of pears in the middle. Peach again. Juiciness. Peach and hints of white wine in the end. Flowery notes. Fruity aftertaste. Phenomenal, well balanced, juicy, very drinkable sour beer.

Bouteille 750ml. Couleur orangée voilée, mousse blanche laissant un anneau sur les parois du verre ainsi quune belle dentelle. Arôme de pêche, côté bonbon Campino aux pêches, Brett, alcool. Goût de Brett, pêche, alcool, légère amertume, légère acidité, un peu poivré, pelure de pêche. Carbonatation moyenne-élevée, corps moyen.

Bottle with Herr Angstmann watching the Euros. Aroma of stone fruit, cherries, pear, wild yeasts, not so much peach. Taste follows aroma but here the peach comes through, balanced perfectly against the base saison and Brett. A high alcohol Cantillon, no artificial sweetness, just the peaches themselves doing the work. One of the very best non-Belgian sours. World class beer, so stoked this showed up in my local bottle shop.

(Bottle No. 20101. Best by: 10/2020. Nez de pêches, à la limite un peu bonbon, Bretts sous-développées. Peaux de pêches jeunes et moins jeunes en développement. Au goût, des pêches et des levures sauvages, du cuir et tout ça sans artifice. Cest vraiment très bon. Mes papilles veulent être inondées. Rien de bien complexe mais tout est délicieux et juste. Bonne présence en bouche. Alcool absolument invisible. Finale colorée par les fruits et par la flore.

Bottle opened at a share. This was one of the best beers Ive ever had. The peach flavor is perfectly blended in with the base sour, creating a drying, tart, funky, peachy beer that tastes complex and refreshing all at the same time. Worth the hunt for a bottle.
Bottle, thanks Mark. Aroma is great, peach, cream, sourness. Taste is great, spritzy, loads of fruit, creamy, Apple. Awesome.

Bomber. Thanks to KL. Severe sour peach nose, mild sourish citrus, ripe apples, and moderate funk. Medium orange/amber color, creamy white head, thick lace. Medium tart fruitinesslight funk rises in sinuses and back palate, gentle bittering, light tart and slightly sweet finish. Thin-medium body, fair to mild astringency. Wonderful mix of aromas, gentle Brett funk. Great stuff.

750 ml bottle. Great peach nose, creamy, some yogurt, grapefruit, just lovely, juicy fruit that is a bit reminiscent of a good ice cider. PRetty orange-gold, cloudy. Great body, fine carbonation that works perfectly. Wonderful flavors of peach and cream. Perfect level of sour, which is there but not in your face. A wonderful beer.

Bottle at Cafe Sara, june 26th 2015. Hazy orange body, big white head. Aroma is funky, peach, tangerine, fruit cocktail. Taste follows the same direction, a clear brett nodge, layers of zesty fruits and lactic goodness, spicy yeast throughout, with a juicy yet dry fruit aftertaste. This is one hell of a nice beer!
Mmmmm... nice and tart. Its a great sour beer, with a satisfying amount of alcohol. It definitely is deserving of its perfect rating.

Like the stuff I've tried from them before, this is solid. The Brett and peach are definitely standing out in there.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dégustée en compagnie de Mademoiselle Irina et Lussier. Cheers! Magnifique robe orangée, claire, rayonnante, trouble et aussi riche que prometteuse. Une superbe tête blanche flotte longtemps en surface mais ne nuit en rien à lémanation des arômes de pêches, darbres fruitiers en fleur et de levures sauvage presque Saison. Une barrique est présente mais jamais envahissante. Je note que la pêche occupe une place de plus en plus grande au fur et à mesure que le liquide augmente en température. En bouche, je suis dabord saisi par un alcool qui ne métait pas annoncé au nez. Cet alcool au notes presque mentholées me pique légèrement les joues. La texture nen demeure pas moins merveilleuse: douce comme la soie, le liquide coule sur ma langue et dans ma gorge avec une douceur inouïe. La pêche est au second plan dans ce liquide qui transporte davantage de saveurs sauvages que fruitées. Peut-être la bouteille a-t-elle trop attendu? Je mattendais à une plus grande expression du fruit. En suis-je pour autant déçu? Pas du tout car nous nous sommes régalés!

Draft at lupulo tap house Santa Cruz. Translucent golden yellow coloured pour witj alarming this white head. Aroma is Clean fresh peach Melba, apricot. Low saison yeast, sweet apricot. Flavour is composed of sweet peach and mango, light wheat, base grains, low saison yeast. Palate is grainy, semi sweet. Moderate carbonation. Nice fruit beer.

Bottle 750ml. @ [ Pre-Borefts Ratebeer evening ] - ABC Beers, Korte Koediefstraat 5, Den Haag, Netherlands 2511CE. [ As Logsdon Peche n Brett ].Gusher !! Unclear matt medium orange yellow color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, moderate to heavy yeasty, funky, yeast, peach, leather, vegetable notes. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate acidic with a average to long duration, tart peach, funky, peach, light minerals. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20150924]

750ml bottle. Hazy golden/light orange shade. White foam. Aroma is bright, fresh, fruity. Must be the best peach character Ive had in a beer. Taste is very juicy, slight tartness, lactic, lemon-lime, grassy, drying end. Drinks nowhere near 10% but does sneak up on you. Very nice.

Bottle: Poured a hazy orangey/golden color ale with a large off-white foamy head with good retention and light lacing. Aroma of light tart notes with funky yeast notes and fresh peach notes is quite awesome. Taste is a great mix between some peach notes with loads of tart notes with light acidic flavours and some funky yeast notes also noticeable. Body is full with limited filtration and good carbonation. Best peach beer I have ever had with lots of dominating flavours and nice balance between the funky and tart flavours.

750ml bottle. Opaque, bright orangey colour with average to huge, thick, creamy, mostly lasting, superbly lacing, white head. Fruity aroma delivers the entire peach panoply, juice, peel, from fresh to overripe, additional subdued funky bretty notes. Taste is dry, slightly tart, fruity, an orgy of peach flavours, funky bretty notes come along well integrated. A masterpiece!

2015 version. Thanks to buckeye boy for this. Poured out a cloudy golden hue. Aroma is huge peaches with almost a hint of champagne. Reminds me of kerns peach soda with a little bit of funk. Such a rad beer.

Pours a very cloudy, dark golden orange color with orange/tangerine edges and a one finger white head that slowly settles into a thick, lasting ring. Spotty lacing left behind. 

Musty brett aroma with some barrel and a boat load of luscious organic peach. Farmhouse yeast and musty funk in the nose with dry brett, damp wood and a very prominent peach presence. Nice fruited saison. The brett really stands out after it warms and is nicely complimented by the oak. The peach character is dominant but doesnt smell artificial nor is it overpowering. Nice balance of different characteristics in the nose. 

Medium bodied with a prominent musty brett character along with dry oak and sour peach. The dry brett flavor is really strong with musty funk perfectly complimenting the farmhouse yeast. Oak is dry/toasted but blends nicely with the bugs and funky yeast notes. Peaches come in at the end with a luscious organic feel. Not cloying or overly sweet with some sour acidity lingering in the finish. Slightly puckering with pit and fleshy fruit flavor. Very complex but its one of most balanced beers Ive ever had. Flavor and mouthfeel are nearly perfect. I wasnt a fan of regular Seizoen or Seizoen Bretta but I highly recommend doing whatever it takes to try this one.

750 ml bottle at home. Pours cloudy orange with a small white head. Intense rich peach aromas with some greasy butter flower as well. Medium body with an imminent spicy bitterness probably coming from the mixture of the base beer, the wood and the fruit tannins, there are quite some tannins. Peach comes back nicely in the flavour, but the bitter spiciness is a bit of a bummer, but a great beer all in all.
[9/24/15] Bottle sample at the pre-Borefts tasting at ABC Beers in Den Haag. Thanks everyone who shared bottles! Orange. Big peach aroma. Sourish flavor with lots of peach. Medium-bodied. Nice.

Bottle split at the ABC Beers pre Borefts tasting
Thin white head. Cloudy blond pour. Peacy aroma. Tart aftertaste. Not badl.

Bottle split at the ABC Beers pre Borefts tasting, 24/09/15.
Hazed orange amber with a decent off white covering. 
Nose is big on peach, pissy citrics, funk, tarte peach, straw.
Taste comprises more tangy peach, subtle brett underpin, soured prunes, funk, light wood must.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with gentle puckerings. 
Solid peach sour, Brett is pretty well honed in.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle at ABC Beers Pre-Borefts Tasting, The Hague. After a bit of gushing, poured hazy dark golden with a medium white head. Aroma of massive peach and a very light funk. Flavour is light moderate sweet and sour. Light medium bodied with light carbonation. Tasty but one dimensional.

Bottle @ Pre-Borefts Tasting, courtesy of the European Crew! Wild Gusher!!! Pours a hazy golden beer with a big white head on top. Aroma of peach, tropical fruits, light tarty Brett. Flavor is sweet and quite Bretty, funky and fruity sweet. Quite a nice sour!
Im Antrunk zwar nach Aprikosen allerdings weder sauer noch anderweitig wirklich aromatisch. Mild herb die Fruchtigkeit ist konstant und allgegenwärtig. Naja... 8/8/8/8/10/8
Pre Borefts tasting 2015. Cloudy gold lasting white head. Big peachy aroma. Some sourness on the flavour. Its OK but nothing amazing. Good peach.

Bottle @ ABC Beers Borefts Pre-tasting. Hazy yellow to light orange color, small white head. Smell and taste are both quite fruity, not too sweet, peach and mango influences. Decent body and carbonation.
Bottle at bullerup pubben. Pours hazy orange with a white head. Aroma of juicy peaches, yoghurt, bretty, flower. Taste is peach yogurt, light sweet, Brett. Well hidden abv, high drinkability.

Bottle. Waxed. Trade with Gunnarolis. Cheers. Pours hazy orange with a white head. Nose is intense fresh juicy peaches and brett. Almost danonimo childrens youghurt - popsickle like sweet but very lovely. Good funk and really dry finish. Tasty ish. Shared with MrOrla.

(750ml 2015 bottle from www.biere-revolution.com) Pours hazy pale orange with a towering head of white froth and lots of lace. Aroma is big and fruit-loaded, lots of peach flesh, fuzzy peach candy, apricot, kiwi, vaguely tropical as well. Dry mineral character, oak notes, a wet overripe fruit funk, very light pepper. Palate is similarly loaded with peach flesh and skin, also apricot-like tartness, orange zest, oak, juicy semi-sweetness initially. Middle to finish dry and mineral, hints of pear, peach pit, apricot, wood, dusty funk like some soft cheese rinds. Finish bone dry, peppery phenolics, wood, hints of Brett, peach pits. Slick medium body with soft creamy carb. My notes dont really do this justice, its super-fruity but complex and balanced, not sour but not sweet either. Feels great in the mouth, eminently drinkable. Magnificent stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2015 Movin to the country Im gonna.. nevermind. Ive been waiting to try this beer for years now, and I get to try it from both the bottle, and draft in the same week. Rating now on draft at the Engine House No 9 Sour Fest. What a surprise! Pours a bright peach color with a slight fizz lasting head. Huge fresh peach and apricot aroma. Flavor matches with an obvious brett background. Well worth the wait.  Also, how the hell is this 10%?  I never paid attention to what it was until after enjoying this, and Im very surprised.  This beer is amazing. Incredible lingering, slightly sour orange fruit flavor. Loved everything about this beer.
Bottle. Cloudy orange with lacey white head. The first thing you get is huge juicy peach flavor, finishing with just a touch of musty Brett funk. Juicy mouthfeel. Absolutely unbelievable.

Bottle. Wow! Tropical fruity notes with soft peaches everywhere. Light brett funk notes on the finish. Basically perfect all around. Complex yet, simple and very enjoyable to drink. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I tried several vintages the same evening, all from 750ml bottles. The peach character varied greatly from the oldest bottle having a very subtle peach character the the more recent batches having a big juicy peach character. The malt character was grainy and the finish dry.

So excited to try this one and have to be honest in that it disappointed. Bright 10 karat/tangelo pour with a tightly-packed ivory crown. Aroma was filled with fresh peaches and nectarines, along with lemongrass, and black pepper. Flavor is less bright and assertive, sharing similarities with the nose and adding some funky barnyard cheesiness. Alcohol was much higher than anticipated and not noticeable in the least. It all sounds amazing but is underwhelming. Will hopefully pick up another to see what I might have missed.

Bottle pour of batch 1,2, and 3. Pours out a hazy golden topped with a white head. Nose is great strong peach notes some yeast and wood. Taste is more and more of the peach some tartness and a nice mellow end. This is one of the best peach beers I think I have ever had.

Bottle at the RBSG grand tasting in Portland 
Hazy straw yellow with a medium sized white head, lots of lacing. Aroma of fresh peaches. Flavors of peaches and perfume 
Good

pours milky yellow with a frothy white head. The nose is the big star of this beer imho. Lots of candy like peach and fruity/mineral pit. Underneath a layer of peppery and bretty saison. Great nose. In the taste I expected a more sour footprint but this was more of a bretty saison than a wildale. Very light flavours, funky and mineral but sadly not much peach. Finishes in a farmyardy, peppery and stony tannic fashion.
Bottle - Batch 1 - Sweet peach sour candy. Hazy pale yellow gold with a decent white head. Sweet and very funky peach. Lots of sweet notes and a bit of funk. Nice.

Thanks to mr. Hoprider for this treat.
Pour a hazy light orange, with a small white head.
The amount of peach in the nose off of this beast is insane. Peaches, slight white pepper, slight grass, slight citrus, slight oak. Taste has plenty of fruity sweetness up front, with some faint acidity. Medium bodied, with a semi flat carbonation.
Bottle. Clear pale golden beer with an offwhite head. Sourish peache, Woody, grassy, a bit nutty funky aroma. Sourish peache Woody grassy herbal earthy flavour.

750 at the chalk bottle share. The aroma is unbievable, peaches and peaches. The pulpy center, right around the pit at the peak of ripeness. Some sweet peach skin. Seriously the best nose on a fruit beer. taste however is just Ok. Fruit, touch of dry Brett. No sour.

One of my favorite beers. The fact that its 10% ABV is ridiculous. Super clean, mildly spicy saison character underneath the delicious tartness and sweetness of the Brett and peach. I could drink this all day. And then I would be dead because its somehow 10%. Amazing beer.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2015 Hazy pale yellow pour with a slight peach hint in the color. Big peachy nose. Luscious. Taste is a bit harsh, bitter with a little fruit. Dry. This is a 2013 bottle and the bugs have been chewing on stuff. Oaky. Would like to try a fresh bottle.

Update: 2015 bottle. Sweeter, more peachy. Better.
Bottle. Hazy golden pour white head. Smells like full peach rings, sweet and tart tones. Sweet peach rings, touch of tartness and Brett tones.

750mL bottle purchased at The Davis Beer Shoppe. The aroma on this is very floral and pleasant with some fruity apricot notes. There is almost a citrus melon character, too. This is really nicely aromatic. The body is a hazy, golden-orange one with a large, strong, fluffy pillowy white head present. Starts with a bit of a cheesy, funky yeast flavoring, before this becomes moderately sweet in the middle. Peach and apricot flavors come through later on, but not too strong. Not much Brett in this, which is fine with me. The mouthfeel is velvety and smooth. A really nice beer, and I normally dislike saison and peach.
Hazy pour, slight gusher. Peach and brett in the aroma. Funky. Big peach taste, Brett, funk, citrus juice, light vinegar, oak. Champagne like mouth feel. Excellent.
Bottle from SHERM1016....thanks! Pours fuzzy orange with peach peach nose....taste is so so sweet with TONS of peaches. Excellent

Huge thanks to Dave for sharing this eons ago, yeah my backlog is this bad. Pours out a nice, somewhat cloudy golden color with a small white head. Aroma is of sweet peaches, light tart/funky brett, mild sour notes and some light vinegar. Taste is of funky brett, sweet peaches, light oranges?? basement, oak, mild vinous notes, nice balance of tart/sweet/funky with not much evidence of the higher ABV. Nice one!

Sample, draught, during the Great American Beer Festival (Denver), savoured on October 3 2014; eye: cream with a caramel hue, hazy, tiny ring of beige head, no lacing; nose: peach, Brettanomyces yeast, light musk, light acidity; mouth: peach, Brettanomyces yeast, light musk, light acidity, light sourness from small berries, finale in musk with presence of peach, medium body, below-average carbonation, lightly harsh texture; overall: fine

Échantillon, en fût, lors du Great American Beer Festival (Denver), savourée le 3 octobre 2014; il : crème avec une teinte caramel, trouble, petit anneau de mousse beige, pas de dentelle; nez : pêche, levure Brettanomyces, léger musc, légère acidité; bouche : pêche, levure Brettanomyces, léger musc, légère acidité, légère aigreur de petits fruits, finale en musc avec présence de pêche, corps moyen, carbonatation sous la moyenne, texture légèrement râpeuse; en résumé : bien

Bottle pour of latest batch at Owl Farm. Pours a golden honey color with virtually no head and a ring of white bubbles. Aroma is insane canned peaches/peach gummis, sweet and honeyed with notes of riesling, pineapple, green apple, cinnamon, and banana. Taste is dried peaches and plums, brandy, and oak, with a somewhat herbal and medicinal finish. Hardly sour at all. Spirit-like and oily. Pretty good but could use a bit of age to dry things out, and Im not sure it quite lived up to the hype.
Bottle pours a hazy yellow/orange with a large white head. Light sweet peach aroma, with soft oak. Sweet peach schnapps taste, with a hit of Brett, and some lacto cream on the finish. Great aroma!

Bottle: Brilliant sunburst color, bright with hints of burnt gold, amber, & orange. Cloudy, opaque. Foamy white head shows decent retention. Huge funk aroma. Expected, as the base beer is funky as hell. Lovely brettanomyces aromas with barnyard funk, musty basement floor, wet hay, cotton, & of course the peaches. Vibrant juicy, authentic, ripe peach aroma. Slight tart but mostly sweet, with underlying notes of wood, white grape, & horsey funk. Hah, wow. The funk is even more amplified on the palate with tons of barnyard & sweaty horse blanket flavors. Musty cheesecloth, damp forest floor, cheese rind... Goddamn, son. Nevertheless, the funk is met in equilibrium with the peaches. HUGE peach flavor. Juicy, sweet, tart, ripe, fresh. Not exactly "sour", but pleasantly tart. Barely acidic... More sweet, almost like peach cobbler... One that was made in a filthy old barnyard stall. Finishing notes of peach, wood, sweaty funk, & Brett. Dry as hell. Absolutely delicious. Theres no way this thing is 10% ABV. Tastes like 4-5% ABV, tops.

From notes. Tasted on 3/16/13 from a gusher of a waxed and capped 750mL bottle at our epic Bottleworks tasting with Curtis, Jedi, and crews from Knoxville and Nashville. Pours murky light orange with a thick white head that leaves thick, messy lace. The nose is like opening a can of peaches with a ton of funky brett and light bread malt. The flavor is peach syrup, tons of funk, and light bread malt, delicious and very interesting. The body is medium with average carbonation and a long funky peach finish.

Bottle at the 2014 Year End Ottawa Tasting. Hazy orange with a white creamy head. Delicate fresh peach and some brett, moderate carbonation and mild body, easy to drink, slightly funky with a pleasant finish.

Bottled. Slightly hazy golden pour with a small off white head. Name pretty much sums this beer up. Loads of brettish notes early on, as it settles the peachy juiciness dominates. Not so smooth but I like how the different layers in this ones come through one at a time. As it warms up the high ABV comes through.

Bottle thanks to Bursprak, Pours hazy dark orange with a white head. The aroma has peach, loads of dry brett which also give you notes of stable, straw and baryard. I also get a weak soapy note. The taste also has some peach and is ultra brett forward. Not tart but more just funky and slight bitter. You get the barnyard, straw and stable notes here as well. Has a slight heat at the end. Ok!

Bottle. Thanks Bursprak! Pours dark cloudy orange with a thick white head. Aromas of sweet peaches, woody notes, barnyard, slightly floral, pretty funky yeast in there aswell, hay. Taste is pretty peachy up front, wood, funk, hay, slightly grainy, some barnyard and stale-like notes.

75 cl bottle thanks to Erik! Pours a murky yellow amber with a white, long lasting head. Aroma is really really dry! Lots of peach for sure, but dry brett, oak and funk really dominates this. Unripe peach, some bitter hops, grains and barnyard. Taste is very bitter up front, but quickly turns more fruity with both slight sour and sweet notes. Dominated by the brettish bitterness and funk. Pretty grainy. The alcohol is there, but 10% is still well hidden! crisp body and medium carbonation.
Thanks Thomas, pours a murky golden. Aroma is peaches tart lemons funky Brett. Flavors are champagne, peaches, brett, leather. Just amazing.

750 ml. bottle. Thanks Mike! Pours a cloudy golden orange with a decent white head. Aroma of fruit, funk, and floral. Taste is peach, fruit, funk, spice, floral, grass, and a bit of wood. Very complex, very drinkable.

En apéro dans un resto indien de Parc-Extension. Lélégance céréalière typique Logsdon badigeonnée dun beurre sauvage aux pêches qui roule sur la langue. Cest immensément juteux et vineux sans lattaque des tannins, effroyable équilibre. De plus, cest impossible de croire aux 10%, quelle séduisante créature!
Smells and tastes peach and yogurt and cream. Very smooth. Totally unique, Ice cream beer. Very lace.

750ml bottle shared by Dave. Poured a cloudy orange straw color with a finger of fizzy white head. Aroma of funk, sour lemon, tangerines, and wheat. Taste is much the same. Light sour funk, grass, rotted oranges, tangerine, and wheat.

750ml bottle via trade. Poured with a small gushing foamy white head as soon as the bottle was opened. Cloudy thick brownish orange body with a fizzy average sized off white head. Aroma is great, fresh crushed peaches, apricot, wood, slight baby aspirin, vanilla muffin, fruity. Big big body with a huge fizzy mouthfeel that is uncomfortable. Flavor of peaches and apricots mixed with seltzer and light oak chips, white pepper and some sour fruit.
Bottle. Thanks Bruce! Pours a hazy yellow golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity peachy bretty aroma. Fruity peachy bretty weak rart flavor. Has a fruity peachy bretty finish.

Shared by westmeister. Tons of peach that really come through in a nice way. Smooth and rich fruit flavors. Lightly tart and effervescent. Finish is a little funky. Some wood to smooth it all out a bit and ground the flavors. Nice and complex.
Been waiting to drink this bad boy. Did not disappoint. Beautifully lightly tart peach, bright but soft peach, dry, bubbly, woody, minor funky, hay, apricot. Lovely stuff.
UPDATED: MAY 3, 2015 Juicy peach smell.  Taste is mildly sour with heavy tart peach and heavy peach skin.  Medium body, medium carbonation, and slight foam.

Bottled. Thanks veliemboys. Pours a cloudy orange yellow colour with a small head. Aroma of juicy authentic peach fruitiness, sweetness and some vinegar. Flavour of peach juice, mild tartness, some pungent wooden notes, a fair amount of yeast and sugary sweetness. After a while some gastric acid notes appear. Medium bodied and slightly dry mouthfeel. Sharp finish. Alcohol is very well hidden. Interesting, but could use a little less sweetness and a heavier body.

75 cl bottle @ home
Aroma has strong peachy notes, some apricot and sweet fruit candy tones. Flavour has fruit candy, peach, tart and acidic tones and . Refreshing, hides the ABV well.

75 cl bottle. Bottle No. #4651. BBE 01/2019.
Pours cloudy golden color with a huge head, somewhat of a gusher. Very sweet aroma, peach kissel to be exact, yeast and some herbal notes too. Peach and hay on the flavor, yeast, earth and toffee. Alcohol is fairly well hidden. A bit too sweet but fairly interesting brew anyway.
4325

750ml bottle from Brewery Creek Liquor Store, Vancouver, BC
Bottle #4651, Best by 01/2019 - 
Pours orange with a massive white head. Aroma of juicy sweet and slightly tart peaches, berries, spices, hints of bretta and funky yeastiness. Taste is juicy peachy, tartish and woody with some bretta, spices and malts. Finish is sweetish juicy, woody and oaky with some warming maltiness, bretta and spices. Quite nice peach overdose.

Bottle thanks to tectactoe for sharing. Very cloudy, light orange pour with huge head that fades to a thick ring. Aroma is dominated by fresh squeezed peaches with just a hint of sourness and brett. Tastes like funky peaches, barnyard, and leather. More sweet than sour. Light tartness. Mouthfeel is probably the smoothest Ive had from a sour. Loved this.

Courtesy of tectactoe
Bottle: The aroma consists of huge peach and nothing else. It pours a cloudy dull orange with a two finger white head that quickly fades to a thin film outlined by a slightly thicker ring. The flavor starts with moderate-heavy peach...mostly sweet, but slightly tart. The finish has lightly tart lemon peel, tart citrus, and a touch of sour grape. Its light-medium bodied with soft carbonation. Overall, Im not a peach fan but this is very refreshing.

Bottle into a snifter.

Light pumpkin-orange, hazy and bright like a sunset. One inch of white fluff recedes fairly quickly. 

Sweet peach syrup, vinegar, saltine crackers, a touch of funk. 

Soft body, a fleece blanket that breaks apart in large-bubbled fizz as it moves. Brilliant blend of funk and sweet fruit, with the perfect amount of funk. Sweet peach is up front, floral, roses, some grass. Lingering funky tartness, green apple and barnyard. Peach rises up again at the swallow. Perfect balance of sweet and sour.

11/VII/14 - 75cl bottle @ Eerste "Er Klopt Iemand Op De Deur" Samson & Gert Bierproeving (aka Epic Beer Tasting III) - BB: n/a (2014-794) Thanks to JefVerstraete for sharing the bottle!
Cloudy light orange to beige beer, creamy off-white head, pretty stable, adhesive. Aroma: pretty fruity, peach, sweet. MF: ok carbon, medium to light body. Taste: little bitter, yeasty, unripe peaches, bit sour, bitter touch, soapy, bit floral. Aftertaste: bit fruity, pretty bitter, yeasty, bit floral, soapy, some spices, coriander.

750 ml bottle into tulip glass, best before 1/2019. Pours slightly hazy golden orange color with a 2 finger dense and rocky white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big juicy and lightly tart peach, apricot, pineapple, lemon zest, white grape, pear, green apple, white pepper, honey, bread, hay, straw, grass, light musty funk, and yeast earthiness. Fantastic aromas with awesome balance and complexity of fruity/spicy/funky yeast, peaches, and pale malt sweetness; with great strength. Taste of lightly tart peach, apricot, pineapple, lemon zest, white grape, pear, green apple, white pepper, honey, bread, hay, straw, grass, light musty funk, and yeast earthiness. Good amount of yeast spiciness and slight tartness on the finish; with lingering notes of peach, apricot, pineapple, lemon zest, white grape, pear, green apple, white pepper, honey, hay, straw, light funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice complexity and balance of fruity/spicy/funky yeast, peaches, and pale malt sweetness; with a great malt/yeast spiciness balance and zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with a very smooth, crisp, and lightly slick/prickly mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a light warming present after the finish. Overall this is an awesome fruited brett saison. All around great complexity and balance of fruity/spicy/funky yeast, peaches, and pale malt sweetness; and very smooth to sip on for the big ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2014 $29.99 for the 750mL bottle purchased from El Cerrito last March. Many thanks, Jazz (truly, I mean it)! On backside of label, it reads:"Bottle No. 5428. Best by: 01/2019". To oversized cognac snifter, it pours a web color orange-tinted Munsell/Pantome yellow with which a snowy white 3 fingers in length stood - if only for a moment. Head retention was stiff and pillowy: had produced beautiful legs resembling US state shapes which had posed like this for over 21 minutes in my glass. Aromas of tangelo zest, toasted coconut meat, candied limes, fennel seeds, champagne mangoes, Virgils Peach Lemonade, Ceylon cinnamon, funk, young oak, sweat, and pilsner malt. Tastes the same with the addition of apple guava, farmhouse yeast, grape tomatoes, blueberry leaves, bay laurel, green cardamom, pomegranate juice, chrysanthmaum blossoms, dried apricots, and wildflower honey. Melon rind, white nectarines, sourdough, Bble paper experienced by swallow. Absurdly drinkable. So much more than just a "sour peach beer".

750 ml bottle poured a hazy gold with a small lasting white head. Aromas of peach, straw and light barnyard. Palate was light bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of straw, peach and light barnyard with a smooth dry lingering peach finish.

First time to have this but its been a long time want. This pours a cloudy peach color with long lasting white bubbles. Nose of fresh tart peach fruit, apricot, wine barrel, and honey. Taste is less tart than the nose, touch of citrusy Brett, lightly sour fresh peach fruit, chopped herbs like basil and lemongrass. Finishes with a soft carbonation, medium length palate finish and earthy peach linger. Amazing beer and refreshing on a hot Texas evening.
Hazy peach colour pour. Sweet peach aroma. Very tart and funky with hay, tart peaches. Quite funky and almost chewy with thick yeast and peaches. Way better as it warms. Fun.

On tap. Pours a hazy gold with a tan head and lacing. It has a fantastic peach aroma and a flavor that is tart peaches up front and a semi-dry finish over a medium body.

Bottle, shared at RBAG 2014 by Kevin. Cloudy orange-gold, aroma is sour and funk, peaches. Leathery peaches, lactic sourness. Tasty.

text: Bottle sample at Muckfest V on 7/12/14. Cloudy orange in color with a medium white head. Nose consists of malt and sweet peach. Sweet malt and tart peach flavor with a slightly boozy finish.

Bottle @ Er Klopt Iemand Op De Deur" Samson & Gert Bierproeving I. Bottle from Lurkaholic, many thanks! Orange cloudy colour. Soft carbonation. Sweet nose of peaches, sour taste with bitter aftertaste of vanilla and tropical fruit. Well balanced. Good American sour!

Bottle at first "Er klopt iemand op de deur" tasting aka EBT3. Thx to everyone for sharing todays beers!
APPEARANCE: clouded blond beer, small unstable white head.
NOSE: peaches, little sour, amazing!
TASTE: peaches, sour, wood, brett very clear, nice!

75 cl. bottle sampled @ "Er Klopt Iemand Op De Deur" Samson & Gert Bierproeving I. Thanks to JefVerstraete! Large frothy white head. Good carbonation. Lightly cloudy. Cloudy light peach orange. Only light horseblanket, barnyard, flowers, nice peach compote but body is dominate by lots of yeast, vanilla, sweet white bread, vanilla sugar, heavy bread, dough, cookie, straw, faint brett in the back. Medium, heavy yeast, creamy body, soft carbonation. Reminiscent of fresh Fou Foune but there is far too much dough, white bread, yeast keeping it down so it is reminiscent but nowhere even remotely near as good. The 10 % ABV is nowhere felt.
Cloudy yellow pour. Aroma is peaches, mild funk, and light sour. Taste is crisp peaches, funk, with a mild sour finish. Good but a bit overhyped.

Pours a hazy golden color. Smells of peach skin and fresh peaches. Beautiful Brett taste, fresh peaches, sweet but not cloying and a little tartness. Delicious beer

Batch 1 bottle. Pours a cloudy yellow orange with small frothy white head that lasts. The aroma is strong brett, oak, funk, and peaches. Thin mouthfeel with nice strong peach, brett, light sourness, wow really enjoyed this one. Very impressive.

On tap at Brouwers Sour Fest. Pours a golden color with a thick white head that leaves great lacing. Smell of peaches, oak and a funky brett smell And sour aspect. Tastes of the same things. This was my favorite out of the 6 beers I had at the sour fest. Very nice peach flavor and the sour is subtle but very present. Very nice and unique.

Bottle from Paul at the Cajun Cafe. Thanks brotha! Shared with Dan and Shawn. Pours a yellowish orange with a large fluffy white head in a tulip. Aroma is a mixture of the peaches and nectarines with the souring yeasts. The taste is simply delicious with the balance of the peaches with the brett base. It is not sweet which happens many times to peach anything. It was enough fruit to know what the taste was, but not cloying or overly fruity. It also wasnt very tart compared to many in this style. Medium body, nice carbonation. Finish is still peaches and brett.

Foamy white lasting head atop a clouded yellowish caramel coloured body. Nose of peach, yeast and salt. Very tart fruit - more apricots than peach - but decent palate throught the finish. Nice but didnt achieve the initial hype.

Bottle at Fruits of the Foeder, 2014-05-17.Hazy straw yellow color, smallish off-white head. Sweet, brett, fruity scent. Brett, acidic, spicy, yeast taste. Yeast aftertaste. Fizzy mouthfeel, low bitterness.

Bottle. Pours hazy orange with white head. Aroma strong of peaches and a touch of wild yeasts, very fruity. Smells amazing! Taste is tart with strong sweet peaches and stone fruits, this beer rocks! YUM!

Bottle from agentzigzag. Thanks Ahmed! Pours a sexy golden-orange with a fluffy white head. Aromas of peaches, peaches, peaches, hay, funk, light bread and earthy hops. Taste is packed with peaches. Managing to keep a light body as well. Nice hay, funk, zest interplay into a nice vanilla-oak after taste. Slightly acidic, moderately tart and damn tasty!

Hazy golden straw pour, white head. Nose is primarily peach with a little funk and oak. Flavor is initially bright lemon acidity, fading to some minerality, fleshy peach, pear, and mild barnyard. Oak adds structure without too much flavor shining through.
Bottle at Culmination Fest: Poured a murky straw yellow with white head. Aroma was loads of peach. Taste was a funky with a peach, oak vanilla, and brett mix. I really dig what Logsdon is doing.

Enjoyed at the de garde 1st anniversary - Pours orange with a white head. The aroma has sharp peach, vanilla, bits of malt and earthy funky yeastiness - very nice and well integrated. It has a medium body with soft carbonation. The taste has nice smooth peach, some woodiness and earth. The finish has mainly peach and lots of rustic wood and earth notes. Excellent.

Draught at Capitol Cider, SeattleBlond color, just hazy, with small head. Delicate friuty aroma. Lean mouthfeel, but with some residual sweetness; nice peachy flavor, apple juice; the Brett is not evident. Balanced beer, refreshing.
Hazy glowing peach color with a light head. Big funk peach smell. Peach sour with a saison spice that blends with the fruitiness of te peach. Medium body.

Bottle. Sour, apricot, funk, grassy, and some citrus underneath. Taste is sour with apricot, and light malts aroma that comes up in the finish which finishes clean. Each sip makes me want more and before you know it your glass is empty. Great beer.
750 ml bottle from the place in Corvallis. Orange pour. Lovely taste. Apricot and peach in body. Brett and tangy tartness. Slight oak in finish. Yup. Thats good.

Another excellent variation of this beer. Peachy and sour apricot. Finishes tart and sour. Cloudy orange pour with good head and lacing. Sweet and sour with great balance. Bottle thanks to GenDV138 at Epic Sour Tasting.

Bottle shared from me at DC Annual Epic Sour Tasting, 2014 bottle. Hazy yellow with off-white head. Aromas of big peaches, light funk. Peaches dominate the nose. Tasting notes of peaches, funk, Brett, citrus. Medium body with a dry finish. Smooth for 10% ABV. Pretty tasty.
From a bottle shared at the DC Epic Sour Beer Tasting. Pours a hazy gold with an off white head. Funky peach nose. Flavors of peach and tart green apple. Smooth and mellow. Very tasty.

Bottle received in trade. Thank you bytemesis! Pours hazy orange with a rather big frothy white head that slowly dissipates while leaving lots of lacing and trace on the glass. Smell is slightly sour and fruity with wheat crackers, barnyard, hay, peaches, leather, orange zest and lemon zest. Taste is slightly sour, tiny bitter fruity and funky with wheat crackers, peaches, barnyard, leather, hay, dry soil, lemon zest, frozen strawberries and hints of clovers and alcohol. Mouthfeel is dry, slightly tart, slightly astringent and medium bodied. Finish is slightly sour, fruity and funky with wheat crackers, hay, dry soil peaches, lemon zest, barnyard, leather and alcohol. Bit too high on the alcohol but otherwise its tasty!
Gul oklar dryck med en arom av aprikoser och skal av grapefrukt. Smak av aprokoser och örter.

Bottle at Fruit of the Foeder, 2014-05-17. Clear pale golden beer with a rich white head. Sourish apricot aroma, woody, lemongrass, floral, hazelnuts, raisins, funky, earthy notes. Sourish apricot flavor, woody, herbal, grassy, hay, spicy notes, earthy, lemongrass, peach, tart, brett notes.

Fruits of the foeder @ Alex
Hazy golden with a small, white head. 
Sourish aroma with citrus and faint notes of hazelnuts. 
Rather sweet flavour. Notes of dried peas and fruits.

Pours hazy orange amber with a creamy tense off white lacing head. Aroma is funky fruity stable cellar apricots. Flavor is pleasantly balanced nutty funky brett apricots astringent and slightly bitter.

Bottle thanks to mike. Aroma of fruit and tartness. Hazy orange color. Moderate white head. Taste is amaz-a-balls. A wonderful peach explosion with some stone fruit noyaux thing going on. Big awesome beer. Want more.

Bottle share thanks to MrsHomers husband. Hazy orange color with white foamy persistent head. Huge sweet tart aroma, pixie stix, juice like aroma as well. Sweet tart, sweet, lots of apricot and peach juice flavor.
Bottle share thanks to Homer. Cloudy yellow with orange hue. Aroma of peaches and sone tart. Taste is light, tart, peach, refreshing. Yummy ass beer.

750ml bottle, thanks Michael, split with my bride. Pours a light yellow-orange with a white head and some lacing. Aroma is a little yeast, Brett, but mostly peaches. Medium on the palate with light, creamy carbonation. Flavor is a little tart, lots of sweet peaches, oak, yeast, Brett, with a tart, Brett finish. Excellent.
Smell of brett, peaches and yeast. Flavor of stone fruit, yeast, brett and wood. Peach really comes through

Took a while! On tap at the De Garde event. Pours a clear copper/yellow color with a large white head. The aroma is just awesome: massive peaches, brett, funky fruit. The flavor is mild tartness, funky Brett, massive sweet fresh peaches. Very natural, a wonderful fruit beer. Damn!

Early 2014 bottle. 
Aroma had lots of Brett character with a balanced peach character. The peach and the Brett notes really combine to make a complex interplay - tropical fruit, pineapple and peach. 
Pours a cloudy, pale, golden orange with a big, pillowy white head. Lots of lacing and small legs. 
Flavor has a medium light peach note with moderate Brett character including a light plastic phenolic note. Light, soft pale malt note with nice soft water. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium high carbonation. Low astringency and medium low alcohol warmth. 
Overall a really nice beer, especially the aroma that is such a complex interplay with the fruit and Brett. Nice soft mouthfeel and water quality. A touch plastic not in the flavor.

Pre-DLD bottle share at Hampton Inn. Pour is light amber with a small white head. Aroma of apricots, peaches, cream cheese, oak chips, and sour funk. Flavor is similar with added notes of white grapes, pale malt, and yeast.

Very hazy amber pour with a nice two finger head that sticks around for quite awhile before receding to a lasting ring.

Palate is peachy, spicy, moderately funky, with a beautiful balance among the three. The tartness is somewhat restrained, but its level works perfectly.

One of the best peach sours Ive had the privilege to enjoy.

On draught at roscoes - pours a cloudy golden with small but lacing white head. Nose of tart fruit, oak. Taste is pleasant sweet and sour peach combined with earthy oak. Another great beer from logsdon.

750 ml bottle purchased at Holiday Wine Cellar some 15 months ago ($23.99). After some difficulty getting the waxed cap off, it pours a hazy sunset-amber hue with two fingers of loud fizzy white foam that soon reduces to a steady half-fingers worth. AROMA of tart lemon, musty basement, unripe peaches, wet oak, and a bit of canned pear. FLAVOR has notable tart peaches, earthy / musty yeast, bretty tang, lemon, unripe tart pear, dry oak, some bready malts. Quite tart but with a nice little bit of sweetness (which increases as it warms). The quite high ABV is nicely concealed under the tartness. Other reviewers find the peach presence to be quite strong, but perhaps I aged this a little too long?? Very nice, but would like to have had more of a forward peach presence. (115, 855)

750 ml wax dipped bottle- Pours completely hazy golden with a thin yet sustains white head and nice lace. Aroma is dusty basement, peaches, funky and bretty. The taste is pureed peaches, dust, minerals, basically funky brett with peaches in a glass! Carbonation is high and body is medium. Loved this beer, would love a case for my cellar, if the budget would ever allow.

Orange hazy in color... Aroma is amazing, almost Better than the beer... Could perfume my house with it... Notes of light peaches, citrus, Brett, light tartness... Flavor is peach flesh up front, citrusy and grainy in the middle, oak and peach pits on the finish... Very complex, maybe a little overhyped as I thought the Saison bretta was just as good... Great beer from a great brewery

Bottle @ Masonry, served in a tulip. Pours lightly cloudy vivid orange with medium thick white head. Aroma is amazing - bright crisp acidity with fresh sweet peaches on the back. Freshness of the peaches on the nose is incredible, like dunking your head into a bushel of just picked peaches. Taste is clean crisp malt; dry, lightly carbonated body; pleasant, perfectly balanced tartness; and faint sweet peach notes throughout, though particularly on the finish, which is dry and clean otherwise. Not sure any beer can live up to the hype this one generates, but this is an amazing beer. Logsdon, please make more!

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2016 INCREDIBLE BEER! Huge peachy nose with some nice funky tones. What a nose! Taste is just explosive fruity peaches but with no sweet tunes. Dry, tartness leaning towards the slightly sour side. Just so much going on. Funk is there but perfectly balanced.

so much peach flavor and aroma, never had this much fruit forward beer that remains in perfect balance. Sweet peach and some funkyness in the arome, flavor is all peach, starts sweet but turns into a very nicely dry and tart finish.. What a surprise this was, and what a fantastic beer.

Rating #1600. 750 ml beeswax-dipped bottle. Aroma is packed with peachy, dusty bretty goodness. Pours hazy cantaloupe with a medium white soapy head that falls in a minute, leaving a collar of foam and some lace. Taste is sour (7/10 on a sour scale), peachy, bretty, very dry. Carbonation is high, but not the annoying champagne-like effervescence that some of these beers have. This is about just right. Nice beer. Now, if I could, the reason I chose this as a milestone rating. The trouble I went to get this bottle is pretty crazy, so it deserves a milestone rating. So--Ive been through Oregon a handful of times, but I dont know it all that well. Coming back from Russian River for Pliny the Younger a few weeks ago, my brother and I decided to hit as many breweries as we could on the way back to Idaho. Logsdon was one of those breweries. According to our brilliant smartphones, all we had to do was make a minor detour after leaving Bend to reach the brewery near Hood River. I remember it getting slightly snowy before it just started dumping on us in a matter of seconds. Perhaps I should have done a bit more research, but I wasnt aware that we were going to have to go through a snowbelt in my wifes minivan to get to our destination. All signs were covered up with snow, completely unreadable, and I just figured it would mellow out. It didnt! It got so we couldnt see 10 feet in front of us. We get these kinds of winters all the time in North Idaho, but I wasnt expecting it here, therefore the brilliant idea of bringing my wifes minivan instead of my truck to save on gas came to be. Blaming my hungover ass for not researching this trip better would definitely be fair. So we keep climbing in elevation and the snow just keeps escalating, and the snowfall is so thick that its not really safe to drive faster than 15 MPH, and there is snow packed up over 6 feet high on either side of the road were on. This goes on for what seems for miles and miles. I dont even know how high up Mt. Hood we were, or even if we were on Mt. Hood! Once again, you can blame this apathy and lack of research on our Pliny-induced hangovers, however pathetic that may sound. At last, we finally begin going back downhill again. We finally get out of the heavy snow where grass and landscape are actually visible and we find what we think might be the place, but theres only one car parked there, so we park next to it. We go up to the barn, not even sure if its the brewery or not, but it looks like the one on the beer labels, so, but...nobody home. After about 10 minutes of walking around this barn, I spot the brewer working. Feeling like a total tourist jackass, I knock on the window. The guy answers, telling me that theyre only open Thursday through Saturday (it was Wednesday). He was just about ready to lock up when we showed up. He needed to get to the post office before they closed, which was in about 15 minutes. I talked him into selling us each a bottle of Peche n Brett, you know, since we came all this way, which he was more than happy to do. After our transaction was complete, we got back in the minivan and tried to get out of there so he could get to the post office. Our intentions were pure, but minivans are not made for farmyard driveways. We got stuck in the mud, and after what seemed like ages, we were able to rock ourselves out of the ruts we were creating. During the entire ordeal, the brewmaster was waiting patiently by the gate so he could lock up, waiting for our dumbasses to get out so he could get to the post office. We ended up having to go *forward* instead of back up the driveway, which meant driving through his yard and over a minor embankment to get back on the road out of there. Going over the embankment, it was very possible that the van could have rolled over like an idiotic turtle. It was one of the most embarrassing things Ive ever been through, and thats why this beer deserves a milestone rating. After waiting in line for 7 hours the previous day for Pliny the Younger and then now this, I just thought, "the things I go through to get good beer... fucking hell!" The end result is always worth it, though, not just for the beer, but for the stories I can now tell.

Taste is dry throughout with a nice sourness that follows and lingers throughout the finish. Overall this is absolutely a fantastically tart Peche!

Well attenuated. I cant say I recognize the peaches used here... Some wheat flavors. Body is light, carbonation low-medium. Overall a letdown for me, I had some pretty high expectation. Near turbid golden with a central dome of light cream foam and little lace. The nose is really nice, peaches, apricots, brett, seltzer, vitamins, tart tones and just a touch of sweetness at the end. Nice tartness on the sides of the tongue, some brett watery character, some bits of lacto style yogurt character and plenty of peach, but the peach seems unripened. Medium on full bodied with hi carb that dissipates quickly and leaves me quite dry - this forces me to take another drink...sadly/not! Nice beer.

Soft on the palate on one level. but has some harsh, borderline infected issues underneath. OK, but pales in comparison to a Belgian example, and not even that great for a US version. Im the lone detractor here, but Im not impressed. Cool ingredients, but half-ass results.

There is also some oak, light tartness, wheat and biscuit malt notes. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Great beer.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2013 Bottle shared with big thanks to beerman6686. Pours a cloudy yellow with a pale white head. Aroma of Brett and tart fruits. Slight peach but not much in the taste. More Brett forward but subdued.
Bottle..Pour is hazy gold with a white head..Nose is nice funk, peach, fruits, dry..Taste is amazing peaches, nice carbonation. spice, tartness, dry, oak..

Taste is smooth peach, vanilla, slight tartness and mellow funk, brett edge with dry finish. Smooth, creamy body. Delicious for sure.

Pours closer to orange than the Oaked Bretta, hazy and lively head.

Smell is funky and tart fruit. Citrus peach and lemon. 

Taste is tart and funky. Horse blanket. Still a bit of peaches. Lighter tart and rustic barnyard toward the tail. 

No heat for 10%, medium body.

Pretty good, but I might prefer straight Oak Bretta.

I was wanting a bit more pucker on this one, but still extremely well done and balanced. Dangerous at 10%!

Citrus and earthy notes follow, along with a dry, mineral finish. Lightly tart. Palate: medium body, soft carbonation. texture felt a little thin at first, but now feels nice and creamy. Overall: the peaches add a really nice element to the base saison, creating a blend that really stands out. Excellent.

Holy cow insane beer thanks to GT2, sour peach and beautiful creation here thanks
Really nice. Good fruit aroma and taste without being overwhelming or sweet. Palate is perfect.

the tongue, very musty, barnish, with a soft underlying peach/apricot like background. &nbsp Not as dry or sour as I would have liked, or bright. &nbsp Seems like a strong wheat base. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Finishes

Aroma of a lot of peaches, a good amount of Brett, a nice maltiness to balance it out, and a light doughiness and oak. Flavor the same with a lot of peaches and Brett and light oak and malts. Average texture. A good beer. EDIT: Not just a good beer, a really, really good beer.

750 from a PUBR groupie. Wow, what a beer. Lemme tell ya somethin about this beer, Bob Griese! The pour was tirbid dark straw with fluffy off-white head. Nose was tart peach, funky yeasty notes, hopcitrus, florals, spice. The flavor was complex and sublime, and I had 6 different people tell me this was the beer of the day. The peach flavor was tart and an accompaniment, not the main bill, with yeasty florals, hopcitrus, and a general farmhouse ale with lighter peach heft from the addition. This beer was delicious, and an example of how to use fruit in the correct brewing fashion.

Bottle shared by kingcecil, thanks buddy. Hazy orange body with a medium White head. Aroma is peach, brett, fresh, flowers. Flavor is flowers, fresh, yeast, brett, dusty, peach, fruity.

Aroma does have fresh peaches (woo hoo), wheat, light grains, and some sweet golden that was not in the other beers. Mouthe feel is medium for rhe style and there is medium carbonation. I was afraid the fruit would die back and got to this quickly but I am super impressed how well it has stood up and can see it going quite a but further and still getting better.

Wow this is fantastic, tons of peach flavors, lightly bretty and really a complex base beer, so much going on

Bottle from my man Walters. Aroma and flavor of faint peaches and Brett. How amazing is this palate? Been waiting a long time for this one and the palate was killer. Not a ton to add about the flavor, but nothing lingers much. Amazing beer.

Flavor is fruity of course, lots of peach, very enjoyable though, some alcohol in the finish, a bit yeasty. Palate is dry, despite the intense fruitiness. Really good.

Bottle 750ml.[2012]
Pours hazy dark blond. Cloudy. Aroma is of peaches, fruits. Taste is of peaches, fruits. Palate: Ligth-medium body. Overall: Awesome peaches. I really dig those fruits. Good drinkability.

Bottle from Tommy, Thanks! Pours a nice light orange with small white head and no lacing. Aroma of peaches, oak funk, smells feally good.  Taste is fresh peaches, oak, tart, a bit cheesy, well balance. Low body and medium carbonation. That was really good. One of the best peach sour i have had.

Aroma is of intense fresh peaches (even after 1+ year), apricots, brettanomyces, cheesy notes and slight sweetness notes. Taste is slightly to moderately sweet with peaches, apricots, fruity brettanomyces, earthy notes, malt and oak. Medium body. Slightly dry. Alcohol is well hidden. Extremely drinkable for a 10% abv beer. Still very fresh. Really fruity/peachy. Almost Belgian like. Great!
Organic peaches make the difference? Thsi one is pretty nicely peached, mayeb it is the ratio. Solid.

Bottle won in richiesds awesome Free Beer Week Contest...thanks Richard! - Pours light hazy amber with a thin foamy white head. Nose has lots o peach, a pleasant warmth and sharpness, and a fairly dry pale malt base. Lots of peach in the taste as well, with dry pale malt and doughy yeastiness. Fluffy and soft with ample carbonation. Ill echo previous comments that this doesnt seem like 10%. Very good stuff.

Lovely spring fruits. Hints of barnyard and wild yeast. The taste is similarly jammy. Loads of apricot and slightly tart peaches. Only moderately sour on the finish. Light body. I cant believe this is 10%. Overall, a very pleasant beer.
From the bottle, hazy light orange color with a white head.  Peach and funky goodness with the just right amount of Brett.  Fruity, funky, tart and good.

The peach character is fresh and deep. It has a very light smoke fruit character. Lots of yeast earthiness. A bit mineral-ish. Its a cultured peach flavor. Not terribly jammy or pungent, but a rustic citrus peach wood flavor. Taste starts with sweeter peaches and turns to sourer drier territory quickly. Finish is lightly bitter. Peach skins. Light mouthfeel. Very smooth and nice for the abv. Very happy to try this one. Big thank you to westcstbrlvr. This is another excellent beer from logsdon.

Subtle aromas of barnyard funk, lemon, subtle oak, white grapes, tart apples, and Bretts. M - rich palate. bright crisp mf. Light medium body. High carb. Nice tart spicy bite. Lingering fruity end. T - peaches, nice funk, tart apples, light lemons up front. Moldy, Earthy notes, bretts, light spices on the palate. Lingering peachy, white grape juice, apple juice and minerally end. O - very good peach sour Really drinkable, hard to tell its 10%. Amazing. 4.4 a fantastic find.

Palate cleanser consumed at THE stouts tasting part 2, many thanks to Bruce. It pours hazy orange with a thick white head. The nose is earth,  apricot yoghurt, peach and light spice. The taste is initially sour, tart peach, apricot, zippy lemon, earth, hay, spice, chalk and light acetic notes, finishing up pretty smooth. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Hides abv very well. Very drinkable indeed. Yum.

Bottle from 16 Tons Cafe, Eugene. Pours a slightly cloudy golden color. Brett most prominent in aroma, little evidence of peaches there. Body is rich yet lively, warming well-hidden. Peaches just a bit in finish, very well-balanced. I get the hype, very tasty!
bottle. pours murky light orange with thin head. peach aroma and slight tart apple. taste was actually not very sour and lots of peach and sweetness

Really peach forward, fuzzy peach skin, hints of bright white grape, lemony, bits of vanilla, slight neutral oak, hints of damp wool.  Medium mouth feel, carb is somewhat loose.  Tart peach up front, picks up lemon and some brett in the mid palate and finishes pretty clean with some mineral notes in the finish.  Doesnt drink at all like 10%.  I would have to agree that this one should be drank now if you want to enjoy the peaches here.

19th March 2013Stouts and Porters II. Thanks to Bruce for this rare palate cleanser. Cloudy gold beer, little cream coloured head. Smells vaguely of Christmas Spices. Palate is light and dry. Slightly bitter seltzer minerals and light mellow peach. Light dry finish. Approachable and drinkable.

Bottle from Alan with Eric and Alan. Pours murky peach orange with thin white head. Light lace. Aromas of peach, pepper, wood, and funk. Taste is sour and tart peach, vanilla, oak, lactic acid. So god damn smooth for 10%. Love this one.

Sweet baby Jesus, this is an amazing example of great beer. Pours a beautiful hazy orangish- yellow. The aroma is the only area where this lacks as I pick up some peach and funk but not a lot more. The taste is absolutely and completely complex. Sweet peach, sour peach, tangerine, bread, butter, cream...the list could go on for quite some time as this evolves on every sip and at nearly every degree as it warms. Superb carbonation and mouthfeel leave me searching for more even though the bottle is empty. Overall, I realize why this was so sought after, its a truly fantastic beer. Glad I got a bottle, wish I hadnt traded the other two but am glad I could spread the love.

Light spices in the nose, some golden fruits, sugary fruits, peaches, mellow funk. Medium to big sweet flavor, light tangy peaches, very little funk, faint lemons. Medium bodied with fine to average, massaging carbonation. Clean finish, a bit more funk, some peach, orange, lemon, hints of minerals. Lovely, very drinkable beer.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2014 Big thanks to GT2/travlr for busting this one open! Hazy apricot pour. Nose and flavor bring tart peach, lactic bite, lemon and other citrus. Good sour character but not as full in the fruit department as the top tier nectar fruit sours out there (Fou Foune or even Cascade Apricot I enjoy more). Still, a pleasure and a treat. 

Rerate 5/17/14- Tried this again with a bit of less of a destroyed palate, and definitely bumping things up. Peach character is vibrant and beautiful, the tang is soft but present. Really well done.

750ml bottle pours a hazy orange with some thin white head.  Nose of peach, white grape, flower pollen, dusty, white wine.  Flavors of acetic acid, peach, wood shavings, white pepper, some distinct biscuit.  Full, tart, acetic finish.

Bottle at Brave Horse Tavern. The beer is a cloudy yellow-orange color with a medium foamy white head that dissipates slowly to a patchy film. Rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of peaches, biscuit malt and yeast. Full-bodied with flavors of tart peaches, oaky brett and yeast. The finish is fruity with a peach and bready malt aftertaste. Very good all around.

750, capped and lightly waxed. Thanks, M! Pours a cloudy medium amber with bright golden edges. Loose creamy, sudsy platinum blond head. Big beautiful fresh fruit nose--not quite like a burst of juice when you bite into a fresh peach, but still very forward and sweet and natural. Its a strong flavorful, just not overwhelmingly explosive. No brett showing. Creamy medium body with a lively carb--not fizzy, just effervescent. Bright fresh fruit on the mid palate. Long sweet finish. Curious what the brett might do to this, given time. The fruit will fade and its hard to see other character popping up out of the brett. It feels like its probably peaking now. Man...what a peak. Wonderful beer.
Hazy gold orange, thin white head. Nose is peaches, funk, light vanilla. Taste is light peaches, light funk, light tartness,wood. Abv masked remarkably well.
On draught at Lucky Labrador Barleywine and Big Beer Festival. Sour aroma. Brett yeast flavor comes through first, with a soured peach finish. Hides alcohol well.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2014 750ml bottle, thanks GT2 and Travlr! Poured a cloudy yellow color with a white head. Aroma is a touch of peach fruits, other stone fruits as well. Flavor had notes of sour fruits, light caramel malts. Flavor is fruity, peaches.

Brilliant peach, heavy bubbling white ring, lightly oily. Nose is sandy peach, light grass, lactic. Flavor is biting, peach and pepper before cream mid and then grassy saison finish. Thin, zesty carbonation.

Bottle from The Trappist. Pours cloudy golden with a thin off-white head and a peach aroma. There is a delicious peach and caramel malt flavor that is medium sour with a delicate yeasty finish. Very nice.

Capped 750 shared by Marcus. Pours hazy light orange with a slight creamy tan head. Aroma is very lightly sour - suggesting pickled peach. Med minus body. Flavor is earthy, sour, unripe peach. Finishes like the flavor. Very nice.

75cl bottle, thanks GT2 and Travlr.  Medium white head atop cloudy apple juice body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, peach, some wood, cherry.  Taste is medium sweet, peach, some wood, light cherry.  Medium body, alcohol well contained.

The beer is hazy and light orange with a small white head. The aroma offers peaches, brett (shocker), wild yeast, funk. Straightforward in both the aroma and flavor. Really nice. Juicy peaches throughout. Mild acidity with fairly low carbonation. A touch of spice in the finish. Mild bitterness as well. Really tasty.
